abstract.p: Letter from Edward Ripley-Duggan on Aug 10 article on printed page versus PC screen

block.p: ''Printed Page Beats PC Screen for Reading, Study Finds'' (Aug. 10), about how material is comprehended more readily on the printed page than on the computer screen, omits one significant consideration. Computer screens (PC -- the Mac standard is slightly different, but comparable) display text at 72 dots per inch. The eye must interpolate and smooth the jaggedness of the screen font, a task that decreases both reading speed and comprehension.

''Printed Page Beats PC Screen for Reading, Study Finds'' (Aug. 10), about how material is comprehended more readily on the printed page than on the computer screen, omits one significant consideration. Computer screens (PC -- the Mac standard is slightly different, but comparable) display text at 72 dots per inch. The eye must interpolate and smooth the jaggedness of the screen font, a task that decreases both reading speed and comprehension.

Since the beginning of the 20th century, the problem of text legibility in printed books has been extensively investigated. Sadly, this research seems to have been largely ignored by the proponents of electronic research and the electronic book.
